revisions.rev:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}} {{Infobox school | name = Gorokan High School | motto = ''And Joy in the Making'' | established = 1976 | schooltype = [[Public school (government funded)|Public]], [[Selective school|Partially Selective]], [[Coeducational]] [[Secondary School]] | principal = Les Clark | viceprincipal_label = Deputy Principals | viceprincipal = Sam Ricketts
and Kim Whealey | city = [[Gorokan, New South Wales|Gorokan]] | state = [[New South Wales]] | country = [[Australia]] {{flagicon|Australia}} | coordinates = {{coord|33|14|32|S|151|30|31|E|display=inline,title|type:edu}} | enrolment = ~1100 | colours = Red and Blue | website = [http://www.gorokanhigh.net/ www.gorokanhigh.net] }} '''Gorokan High School''', is a [[secondary school]] located in [[Gorokan, New South Wales|Gorokan]], [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]]. Established in 1976, the school was housed in temporary buildings in Dudley Street on the site of what was to later become Gorokan Public School. It moved to its current location in Goobarabah Avenue in 1977. Its first principal was Gwen Foley, who was the first female high school principal on the NSW Central Coast. She retired in December 1982. Current student enrolment is more than 1,100.[http://www.education.net.au/profile/3527/GOROKAN-HIGH-SCHOOL "Gorokan High School"], National Education Directory, 2007 ==Online mentoring== Gorokan has successfully trialled [[The Smith Family]]'s OnTrack online mentoring program which has produced a marked increase in engagement by students and school attendance.Taffel, Jacqui. [http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/09/19/1063625208511.html?from=storyrhs "Buddy system"], ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'', 20 September 2003. Accessed 2 May 2007. ==Extracurricular activities== The school's wind orchestra has been recognised internationally for its performances.[http://gorokan-high.nsw.edu.au/faculties/prospectus/prospectus%20index.htm Gorokan High School: Prospectus], accessed 1 May 2007. The 57-member wind orchestra was invited to perform at the 1999 [[Banff, Alberta|Banff]] International Festival of School Orchestras and Bands, where the orchestra was chosen to make the final performance, for which they received the festival's only standing ovation.[http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/PARLMENT/hansArt.nsf/V3Key/LA19990525031 GOROKAN HIGH SCHOOL WIND ORCHESTRA], [[Parliament of New South Wales]], Private member statement made on 25 May 1999, accessed 1 May 2007. In 1994 the band went to the World Resort Expo in Japan. They played at this as well as the opening to Kansai International Airport. The wind orchestra was going to take a 2003 tour of China however the [[SARS]] outbreak prevented the trip.Bellinger, Caroline. [http://www.newstext.com.au/docs/DTM/2003/get.jsp?docid=DTM-20030325-8-003-4070522V7@NSW-METRO-2004-2003 "Musicians tune into China trip"], ''[[The Daily Telegraph (Australia)]]'', 25 March 2003. Accessed 1 May 2007. ==Notable Alumni== In his early life [[Matthew McConaughey]] spent 12 months attending Gorokan high as a [[Rotary Youth Exchange|rotary exchange student]].{{cite web | title=ONE news | work=McConaughey credits Australian town | url=http://tvnz.co.nz/view/page/425826/696966 | accessdate = 22 December 2006}} ==Water conservation initiative== The school successfully bid to the [[Government of Australia|Australian Government]] Water Fund for over $A45,000 for a water conservation initiative that will save 442,000 litres of water each year.[http://www.communitywatergrants.gov.au/grants/round1/nsw-1-2999.html "Round 1 Community Water Grants Projects"], Australian Government Water Fund, 29 August 2006, accessed 2 May 2007. ==New skill centre== [[Gary Hardgrave]], Minister for Vocational and Technical Education, on 17 January 2005 announced $A350,000 funding for the construction of a skill centre at Gorokan.[http://www.dest.gov.au/ministers/hardgrave/H_Media.asp?y=2005&m=01 "$350,000 for new skill centre"], Minister for Vocational and Technical Education, 17 January 2005 ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1976]] [[Category:Public schools in New South Wales]] [[Category:High schools in New South Wales]]
